ygData.subject: Re: word of possession
ygData.msgSnippet: EQ_spell_research mail list recipients: I am copying you on a message I have sent to cristie .  My sons and I apologize to anyone who may have received the
ygData.messageBody:
EQ_spell_research mail list recipients:

I am copying you on a message I have sent to "cristie". My sons and I apologize to anyone who may have received
the happy99.exe worm from this account. They were merely unwitting participants, having received it from someone
else. Please check your C:WINDOWS\SYSTEM\ directory for a file named SKA.EXE or alternatively do a file search
for happy99.exe. If these exist, then follow the directions below to get rid of it.

Regards,
Richard Kubin & Sons

Cristie:

Excuse me. I am not sure who you are, but you certainly do not possess many
manners, either Internet or otherwise. This account belongs to me, but is used
primarily by my two sons, aged 12 and 14. They are primarily using it for
playing games (Everquest mostly) as well as for game info and trading magic
cards. They had no idea that this computer was infected with the worm
happy99.exe. After they read your first nasty email, they immediately told me-
having scanned prior emails, I was able to deduce that one of them had received
it on Mar.12 from some other unwitting soul and being a somewhat naive user, he
had opened it, thereby infecting this computer.

What any polite person would do upon receiving something like the happy99.exe
worm in an email attachment would be to inform the sender of their infection.
It is obvious that you know very little about this type of problem (it is
technically a worm, not a virus). It took me about five minutes to find out
about this worm (doing a yahoo search) and another five minutes to get rid of
it.

In the future, I would hope that you show a little more respect for your fellow
users and rather than making threats, help try to solve the problem. Try to
remember that some users are still somewhat young and naive when it comes to
computer and internet use and we should try to help where we can. I have made
sure that my sons now understand more about internet security and the dangers
of viruses etc. A good rule of thumb is never to open any attachments unless
you are absolutely sure of the source.

The following link provides information on what the happy99.exe worm is and how
to get rid of it:
http://www.symantec.com/avcenter/venc/data/happy99.worm.html

It is very straight forward and I include instructions here for your benefit:

VirusName: Happy99.Worm
Aliases: Trojan.Happy99, I-Worm.Happy
Likelihood: Common
Region Reported: World Wide
Characteristics: Trojan Horse, Worm
Description:
This is a worm program, NOT a virus. This program has reportedly been received
through email
spamming and USENET newsgroup posting. The file is usually named HAPPY99.EXE in
the email or article attachment. When being executed, the program also opens a
window entitled "Happy New Year 1999 !!" showing a firework display to disguise
its other actions. The program copies itself as SKA.EXE and extracts a DLL that
it carries as SKA.DLL into WINDOWS\SYSTEM directory. It also modifies
WSOCK32.DLL in WINDOWS\SYSTEM directory and copies the original WSOCK32.DLL
into WSOCK32.SKA. WSOCK32.DLL handles internet-connectivity in Windows 95 and
98. The modification to WSOCK32.DLL allows the worm routine to be triggered
when a connect or send activity is detected. When such online activity occurs,
the modified code loads the worm's SKA.DLL. This SKA.DLL creates a new email or
a new article with UUENCODED HAPPY99.EXE inserted into the email or article. It
then sends this email or posts this article. If WSOCK32.DLL is in use when the
worm tries to modify it (i.e. a user is online), the worm adds a registry
entry:
HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnce=SKA.EXE
The registry entry loads the worm the next time Windows start.

Removing the worm manually:

1.delete WINDOWS\SYSTEM\SKA.EXE
2.delete WINDOWS\SYSTEM\SKA.DLL
3. in WINDOWS\SYSTEM\ directory, rename WSOCK32.DLL to WSOCK32.BAK
4. in WINDOWS\SYSTEM\ directory, rename WSOCK32.SKA to WSOCK32.DLL
5.delete the downloaded file, usually named HAPPY99.EXE

Windows prevents you to do step #3 and #4 above if the machine is still
connected to the Internet. The file "windows\system\wsock32.dll" is used
whenever the machine is connected to Internet (i.e. through dial-up or LAN
connection).

Sincerely,

Richard Kubin
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

> From: Cristie <cristie@...>
>
> Who the HELL do you think you are sending virus executables out to people
> on a mailing list. I have written to your isp about this matter and I am
> certain they will take action on it. Spreading viruses is a felony. You
> don't deserve to have an internet account with any isp in my humble opinion.
>
